DOCNAME: CASE OF SULEJMANOV v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
CONCLUSION: No violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Substantive aspect);Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Procedural aspect)
JUDGES: Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Volodymyr Butkevych
TEXT: CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant and his friend PERSON , both of GPE ethnic origin , were stopped by CARDINAL police officers near the village of GPE on suspicion of having stolen CARDINAL sheep . The police officers , without asking any questions , immediately started to beat him and his friend on their heads and bodies with their truncheons , which caused bleeding from the applicant ’s mouth and nose . They were then put into the police car and driven to the village of GPE , where the theft had allegedly occurred . CARDINAL of the police officers called over the owner of the sheep in order to confront him with the applicant . The police officer started to swear at him and said : “ All gypsies will remember me forever . I can sacrifice you all . ” The applicant was handcuffed and beaten by police officers with truncheons and by the owner of the sheep , who was using the branch of a tree .

CARDINAL . TIME the applicant and his friend were taken to the police station , where they were made to lie on the ground in front of the door and beaten by CARDINAL police officers . Once inside the police station , they were tied to a bench in the hall and beaten up again . As the applicant was terribly thirsty , he asked for some water , but the reply was “ there is no water for gypsies ! ” They remained tied to a bench TIME ; they were released in TIME .

CARDINAL . After his release on DATE , the applicant went the same date to ORG ( the “ hospital ” ) , where a plaster cast was put on his broken left arm . As he had no money to pay for the medical assistance , he used his cousin ’s medical identity card and therefore his name , instead of the applicant ’s name , appeared in the hospital ’s register . In the hospital ’s register , the injuries were described as “ fracturae ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE , after TIME , the applicant and his CARDINAL friends , S. NORP and PERSON , hired a taxi in PERSON and went to the village of PERSON with the intention of stealing sheep from PERSON They told the taxi driver that they were going to collect CARDINAL sheep from a relative and sell them in PERSON .

CARDINAL . On arrival in the village , the applicant and his friends broke into the cellar of PERSON house , stole CARDINAL sheep , put them in the taxi and then headed for PERSON . In PERSON , they went to the Roma quarter and tried to sell the sheep for QUANTITY . They refused an offer of MONEY and headed back towards PERSON with the sheep in the taxi .

CARDINAL . At TIME the police stopped the taxi in the vicinity of the village of PERSON in a routine check . Their suspicions were aroused by contradictory explanations given by the occupants of the car about the sheep . The police requested information on the radio as to any reported theft .

CARDINAL . At TIME had reported the theft of his CARDINAL sheep . A police van arrived and the taxi driver was instructed to follow it to PERSON . At TIME , they arrived in PERSON . The applicant and his friends were instructed to unload the sheep . PERSON arrived at the scene and began to swear ; he hit the applicant with a stick several times on the upper body and claimed that the applicant had stolen livestock and property from him before . The police ordered PERSON to stand back and prevented any further blows to the applicant .

CARDINAL . At TIME the police took the applicant and his friends back in the police van to PERSON . The applicant , his friends and the taxi driver were interviewed . The applicant complained of pain in his arm and stated that PERSON had hit him with a stick . This was allegedly corroborated by the taxi driver .
CARDINAL . At TIME on CARDINAL DATE the applicant and the others were released . The same day , PERSON lodged a criminal complaint with the police .

CARDINAL . The taxi driver confirmed that it had been on DATE that CARDINAL persons of GPE origin , including the applicant , had loaded the sheep into his car in the village of GPE and taken them to PERSON . After being stopped by the police , he had been instructed to follow the police van to the village of GPE , where the sheep had been returned to PERSON No mention was made that ORG had hit the applicant .
CARDINAL . The applicant , PERSON and PERSON described the circumstances concerning the sheep theft which had happened on DATE . None of them indicated that the applicant had been hit by PERSON

CARDINAL . On DATE the police lodged criminal charges of aggravated theft with the public prosecutor against the applicant and his CARDINAL friends . It was noted that the incident had occurred on DATE . No mention was made of any injuries having been sustained by the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was convicted by ORG on CARDINAL counts of theft ( verdict K. No . CARDINAL ) including the CARDINAL relevant to the present case . According to the judgment , the offence had been committed on DATE . The applicant was sentenced to DATE and DATE imprisonment . On DATE ORG upheld the trial court ’s decision and confirmed the sentence .

CARDINAL . On or about CARDINAL DATE , Mr PERSON , as the applicant ’s representative , brought a civil action before ORG ( LOC суд ORG ) against the respondent ORG and ORG for compensation for non - pecuniary damage sustained as a result of police brutality inflicted on him .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG Instance dismissed the applicant ’s claim as ill - founded . It found insufficient evidence to establish that the applicant had been injured by the police officers on duty . It accepted the testimony given by the police officers , who said that the applicant had been hit with a stick by PERSON , the owner of the sheep . It found that the applicant had not been beaten by the police officers and that no force had been inflicted on him while he was detained in the police station . The court established CARDINAL DATE as the date of the incident . It stated , inter alia ,

“ ... when PERSON [ the owner of the sheep ] saw the persons who had stolen the sheep , he started to hit [ the applicant ] with a stick , as he had stolen sheep from him before . The officers on duty intervened to protect the complainant ( the applicant ) from PERSON without hitting him ... During the arrest , they ( the applicant and his friend ) did not resist and the police officers did not use any force ... the court established that the complainant had been beaten by PERSON when the sheep were returned to him ... these witnesses ( the police officers who were on duty on CARDINAL DATE in the police station when the applicant was taken into police custody ) stated that they had questioned him and had not used force against him , as he had not resisted ... during the questioning , he had not complained that he was injured or felt any pain . He only complained that he had been taken to PERSON , who had hit him . They ( the police officers on duty on the decisive date ) stated that they had not noticed any injuries on [ the applicant ’s ] body . ”

CARDINAL . The applicant asked the court to hear PERSON , as an eyewitness to the incident , the cousin who had lent him his medical card and the doctor who had examined him . The court did not hear PERSON or the applicant ’s cousin , as they had been imprisoned in GPE and were therefore considered “ unreachable ” by the court . It ruled that their examination would be irrelevant , as other evidence did not show that he had had any injuries during the police investigation . It accepted as possible that the applicant had visited a doctor with another person ’s medical identity card , but that it had not been in relation to injuries inflicted by police officers .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed an appeal by the applicant and upheld the lower court ’s decision . The court found that the lower court had reasonably established that PERSON , the owner of the sheep , had inflicted the injuries on the applicant by hitting him with a stick . The police officers had intervened to protect the applicant from further attacks . It endorsed the lower court ’s reasoning that the applicant had not been beaten in the police station while in custody . It established that even if the lower court had heard the witnesses proposed by the applicant , they would not have altered its findings , as it had found that the police officers who had arrested him had not used any force and had not inflicted any injuries on him .

CARDINAL . On or DATE the applicant requested the public prosecutor to lodge with ORG an application for protection of legality ( барање за заштита на законитоста ) . Referring to the outcome of the civil proceedings , he did not provide the public prosecutor with the identity of the police officers concerned .
CARDINAL . On DATE , the public prosecutor notified the applicant that there were no grounds for lodging that remedy with ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE , PERSON , as the applicant ’s representative , lodged a criminal complaint ( кривична пријава ) with ORG ( Основно Јавно Обвинителство Штип ) against an unidentified police officer . In the complaint , the applicant set out an account of the incident which had allegedly occurred on DATE . As evidence , the applicant offered his own testimony , that of his friend PERSON and that of the doctor who had examined him and put a plaster cast on his hand , and proposed consulting the hospital ’s register . He stated , inter alia ,

“ ... TIME a police officer , who I do n’t know , hit me with a truncheon , breaking my left arm . The police took me to the Štip Medical Centre where a plaster cast was put on , which I kept on for DATE ... “

CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant ’s legal representative wrote a letter to the public prosecutor , stating that a criminal complaint had been lodged DATE before and that since then he had received no information as to whether any steps had been taken to identify the offenders and initiate a formal investigation .

CARDINAL . As there was again no reply , on DATE the applicant ’s lawyer sent another letter to the public prosecutor , requesting to be provided with information about any action taken concerning the applicant ’s complaint and about the identity of the offender(s ) .

CARDINAL . In a letter addressed to the applicant on DATE , the public prosecutor responded that his office had acted with regard to the criminal complaint at issue by officially requesting additional inquiries from ORG ( “ the Ministry ” ) . However , as of that date his office had received no information from the said ministry .

CARDINAL . On DATE the public prosecutor issued a “ written conclusion ” ( писмена констатација ) concerning the applicant ’s criminal complaint . It was based on a statement by the taxi driver given on DATE and on the criminal case file against the applicant . As stated therein , the taxi driver attested that PERSON had hit the applicant and S. NORP with a stick and that the police officers involved had not had recourse to any physical force when arresting them . There were , accordingly , no grounds for the public prosecutor ’s intervention . That decision was served on the applicant ’s representative on DATE , after the ORG ’s admissibility decision given in the present case .
CARDINAL . The statutory provisions relevant for the present case were described in the PERSON case ( see PERSON v. the former GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL , DATE ) .
